top_comment.author: tshorse

comments.text:
California, with all of its faults, at least has massive amounts of public 
property so there's always that option for hunting. I've read that 98% of 
Texas is privately owned. Nevada is the true outdoorsman's paradise since 
early all of it is Federally owned.
comments.author: Zachary Sanders

comments.text:
I don't know of anyone that will let hunters come out.  I'm on a lease. 
 Most of the property is owned by corporations so finding a place to hunt 
usually takes knowing a friend of the owner/manager.  The property owners 
will even split up the rights, with some lessees having farming rights 
while others will have hunting rights.  It's a pain.  I used to hunt Cougar 
Run Ranch.  It's a good day lease if you don't have time for an annual 
lease.
comments.author: Christopher Haist

comments.text:
+Christopher Haist If the rancher would like some Marines to come help him 
reduce his population, pls do let me know their contact info!
comments.author: Ian Stone

comments.text:
+tshorse I looked up Wild Hog Adventures and they charge $300 to hung two 
hogs. Considering that the owner has to arrange for you to come on to their 
property and also concerns about liability (whether or not a waiver is 
signed, someone can always sue), I think $300 is pretty fair (and $30 to 
clean), considering that it is open to the public.
comments.author: Ian Stone

comments.text:
There's a ranch about a mile from where he is hunting that charges $1/pound 
for hogs, all day long.
comments.author: Christopher Haist

comments.text:
I agree. Seems too opportunistic for my tastes. That would be like me 
calling my local exterminator and offering to let him kill all the rats in 
my house (if I had that problem) for a mere $1200 payment TO ME!. Crazy.
comments.author: Zachary Sanders

comments.text:
Most people charge a few hundred bucks.The problem is letting people on 
your land or lease that you don't know.People will shoot deer and trash a

even to hunt pigs
comments.author: gsppuffer

comments.text:
+Adrian M
You certainly do not have to pay anything. Just go up to practically any 
farmer down there and most will gladly give you permission to hunt on their 
farm for feral hogs for free. Hell, I bet some would pay you a bounty for 
each one you kill. Feral hogs cost each farmer thousands in crop damage 
annually.

top_comment.author: ShadeOps45

comments.text:
+ShadeOps45 Actually on the form 1 (creation form) and the form 4 (transfer 
form for individual ownership) all "suppressors" are listed as Silencers 
through the government. Yes it seems like an incorrect name, however it is 
the legal term used by the government and thus they are "silencers" even 
though they only "suppress" the sound of the gunshot. :)
comments.author: OrignalRecipe92

comments.text: +Keith Warren Aw you are right sir sorry about that! good hunt and video
comments.author: ShadeOps45

comments.text:
More people search for the word "silencer" instead of the word 
"suppressor." The word "silencer" is used for search engine purposes. 
Notice in the description I use the word "suppressed."

comments.text:
Most places I've seen have restrictions on how many rounds you can put in 
something like an AR to encourage good marksmanship. I saw a video on here 
of a guy "hunting" coyotes with an AR and tracers. And he missed like 5 
shot and was still trying to hit it while it was running away and he's just 
blasting away. If your going to kill something at least make the shot count 
and don't shoot randomly at it. Plus animals like that get aggressive when 
wounded.

comments.text:

handguns. Most handgun calibers are already subsonic or close to it.

comments.author: Garrett Rowser

captions.text:
Alright, the wind is really swirling like
crazy. I mean, I don't know if you've ever

hunted in wind or not in timber, but it really
gives you a lot of fits. So, we're going to

try and stay in some open country, and eliminate
our scent as best as possible. Stay in some

open country. We've got about an hour and
a half before dark. And, although I know that

this Savage Rifle shoots like a Savage Rifle,
that doesn't surprise me, but what surprises

me is the fact that they have put the suppressor
inside this sleeve right here, have not affected

the accuracy at all, and now, I'm just hopeful
that we can get close enough to a pig, but

we're going to have to take some chances and
stay in some open spots because of the wind.

Here at the ranch, we hunt all different ways.
You can hide in a pop up blind, you can stand,

you can, you know, stalk, we have ladder stands,
just pretty much however you would like to
do it.

Today, the wind's blowing a little bit, and
you know, the hog's sense is, they're pretty

sharp. They smell good, they hear real good.
Today, Keith's going to try and do a spot

and stalk hunt, and with the wind blowing,
he's got his work cut out for him. When you're

on the stalk hunt, you really need to pay
attention to your scent control. You have

to have the wind right, the wind has to be
blowing in your face and you have to be extremely
quiet.
Here it goes.

Look at this. Look at this. This is unbelievable.
How is that. A Model 10 Savage in .308 caliber,

and I tell you what, the pigs, I'm here, they
had no idea. I mean, I'm sitting here, I sprayed

down, the wind is going everywhere. Now, Billy
has got more pigs out here than you can shake

a stick at. He's the guy who runs this place
out here. This is a half hour from the Houston

Intercontinental Air Port. I don't know if
you can here that, but there's pigs over here

squealing. Anyway, half hour from the Houston
Intercontinental Air Port, he has the most

smoking deal on pig hunts you can ever imagine.
So anyway, we've got an hour before dark and
I think the pigs are in bad trouble.

Now, Okay. I'm all about shot placement. And,
any ethical hunter is about shot placement.

When you're shooting a suppressed rifle, it's
especially important for proper shot placement.

And, if you take a look right here, that right
behind the ear, that is a perfect shot. This

guy right here, take a look at the shot placement
on him. Absolutely the same thing, right in

the brain. And, so, what happens is it kills
them quickly, and ethically. OK, this is a

Savage Model 10, .308. It's been customized
by my friends over at Dark Horse Arms. And,

those guys wound up and put a suppressed barrel
on here, and actually there's a sleeve on

top of the barrel that came with the Savage
rifle. But anyway, it's an absolutely incredible

piece of equipment. But the deal is, when
you're shooting something like this, you're

shooting subsonic loads. You need to keep
that in mind. Your velocities are going to

be slower, so your distance that you're going
to shoot is going to be a lot closer. Therefore,

making sure that you have proper shot placement
is absolutely paramount. But, these right

here, these are two awesome pigs, two boar
pigs, really good. And look at the cutters

on this one. I mean, this guy right here.
Look at the cutters on that dude! That's good.

When you come out here, to Billy's place,
he offers packages that are two days long.

And, you get to kill two pigs. So, we'll have
his telephone number coming up here in a little

bit. You can get a hold of him, he's a good
guy. Billy's a good man. We're going to get

these guys taken care of and eat some real
good barbecue tonight. And then tomorrow,

I'm going to see if I can get the third little
piggy.

title: Hog Hunt with Silencer | Dos Piggies
